item.title: Something scary... (for Americans anyway)
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote="`Alec, post:2, topic:423583"][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=525094.msg3833556#msg3833556 date=1322744207]

Wanting to kill humans isn’t exactly normal, you might want to seek psychological help/guidance (your desire is most likely caused by a personality disorder). I don’t understand how killing an animal is more cruel than killing a human (or vice versa). No one life is more important than another. I don’t think anything justifies killing another human.

I’ve wondered about this and decided people feel more sorry about a dead animal than a dead human because animals are innocent.
[/quote]

There’s no such thing as a justified kill, though.[/quote]

I disagree.

“The righteous shall rejoice when he seeth the vengeance: he shall wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.” Psalms 58: 10.
It all depends on what what you believe.

Read full topic

item.title: Something scary... (for Americans anyway)
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:34, topic:422428”]His motives are obvious, but his facts are not. I watched the video for a half an hour. The ideas he was talking about regarding devaluing a currency are actually spot-on. He’s right to suggest the United States governments are significantly in debt, and the only way to pay off this debt is to print more money (well, that’s not exactly true, but that was his argument). In that sense, as the amount of currency increases, it inflates that economy and devalues the currency relative to the rest of the world.

One thing I am uncertain on is the devaluing concept being bad. A strong versus weak currency isn’t a good versus bad scenario. Strong and weak currencies are two opposing states, both with benefits and drawbacks. A weak U.S. dollar means that foreign investments are more expensive, exporting is generally less profitable, and prices in the United States are more expensive (aka, it sucks for us). Nevertheless, the complete opposite happens for other countries. A weak U.S. dollar means other countries can invest easier in U.S. assets, sell products to the United States for more profit, and overall enjoy the cheap U.S. prices. I would say based on that alone, his entire plan is flawed.

Furthermore, there are more complex cases to look at. Yes, we are printing more money to try and pay off debt, but most of our debt is being paid off with more debt. This isn’t because we are stupid, but because the United States holds one of the core economies in the world. This means when we aren’t doing good, we sell bonds to countries like China, who return the large stockpiles of U.S. dollars they own. It’s a very cyclical and extremely complicated process, but it’s not quite as unsound as he suggests. I won’t deny there is extreme uncertainty in the financial future of the United States, but it’s not something the entire world can escape. Even if he was entirely right in all his reasoning, the world could not afford the United State suddenly dipping into depression.

Inb4someone says I’m under the normalcy bias. That was rather clever of him to include, haha.[/quote]
So you’re saying it will get worse before it gets better?

Read full topic

item.title: Something scary... (for Americans anyway)
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

[quote=“m1lkman, post:33, topic:422428”][quote author=Andrew Ferguson link=topic=525094.msg3824404#msg3824404 date=1322055034]

This generation is obsessed with zombies.

We are not obsessed, we just live for them.

But they don’t exist. How can you live for something that doesn’t exist and if they did exist, uslike me, i’m a fat, non-social, computer geeks would be the first to die/convert to zombies.

Don’t group me in with you, I’m skinny, have a job, a girlfriend, and friends. Kthxbia, you don’t get to come in the zombie safe house now. (:
[/quote]

Just screwing around. People still gnna get owned by Zombies… If you ask me, the only people who will actually survive a zombie apocalypse are those with military experience. The movies make absolutely no sense when a nerd who plays WoW all day can survive longer than a well-trained SEAL. I don’t see it.[/quote]
I guess I have to unlock my zombie door for you now. (:

Read full topic

item.title: Something scary... (for Americans anyway)
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

His motives are obvious, but his facts are not. I watched the video for a half an hour. The ideas he was talking about regarding devaluing a currency are actually spot-on. He’s right to suggest the United States governments are significantly in debt, and the only way to pay off this debt is to print more money (well, that’s not exactly true, but that was his argument). In that sense, as the amount of currency increases, it inflates that economy and devalues the currency relative to the rest of the world.

One thing I am uncertain on is the devaluing concept being bad. A strong versus weak currency isn’t a good versus bad scenario. Strong and weak currencies are two opposing states, both with benefits and drawbacks. A weak U.S. dollar means that foreign investments are more expensive, exporting is generally less profitable, and prices in the United States are more expensive (aka, it sucks for us). Nevertheless, the complete opposite happens for other countries. A weak U.S. dollar means other countries can invest easier in U.S. assets, sell products to the United States for more profit, and overall enjoy the cheap U.S. prices. I would say based on that alone, his entire plan is flawed.

Furthermore, there are more complex cases to look at. Yes, we are printing more money to try and pay off debt, but most of our debt is being paid off with more debt. This isn’t because we are stupid, but because the United States holds one of the core economies in the world. This means when we aren’t doing good, we sell bonds to countries like China, who return the large stockpiles of U.S. dollars they own. It’s a very cyclical and extremely complicated process, but it’s not quite as unsound as he suggests. I won’t deny there is extreme uncertainty in the financial future of the United States, but it’s not something the entire world can escape. Even if he was entirely right in all his reasoning, the world could not afford the United State suddenly dipping into depression.

Inb4someone says I’m under the normalcy bias. That was rather clever of him to include, haha.

Read full topic
